gravity_system: Engineered Roof Trusses, Loadbearing Walls, Concrete Footings
other_materials: 29 GA. Diamond Rib Steel Cladding, 29 GA. High Tensile Century Rib Steel, Plywood, Pressure Treated Wood
key_elements: Roll Up Door, Ridge Vent, Uplift Clips, Purlins, Scabs, Truss to Plate Connection, Brace to Post Connection
overall_building_description: The Elysa Vahrmeyer Farm Storage Shed is a meticulously engineered agricultural structure designed to withstand both gravity and lateral loads through a combination of engineered roof trusses and strategically placed diagonal bracing. The roof system is composed of engineered trusses spaced at 4'-0" on center, reinforced with 2x4 roof strapping at 2'-0" on center, and clad with 29 GA. high tensile century rib steel. The trusses are secured using uplift clips or fasteners as per details D1 and D2, ensuring robust load transfer from the roof to the supporting walls. The roof also incorporates ridge vents as per Ontario Building Code (OBC) requirements, facilitating proper ventilation. Diagonal bracing is a critical component of the lateral load-resisting system, with 2x4 struts and diagonal braces anchored using 3Â½" nails at specified intervals, providing lateral stability and preventing structural deformation under wind loads. The foundation system comprises concrete footings and walls, with a minimum of 6 inches of compacted granular 'A' on undisturbed soil to ensure adequate bearing capacity and settlement control. The foundation plan specifies the use of pressure-treated wood (PT) for elements not in contact with concrete, enhancing durability and resistance to moisture-induced decay. The wall framing incorporates shear blocks and uplift scabs, with 2x6 ripped shear blocks placed under each truss between plates to facilitate shear transfer and maintain diaphragm action. The building elevations reveal the use of 29 GA. diamond rib steel cladding, providing both aesthetic appeal and weather resistance. The structural integrity of the wall framing is further enhanced by the use of 2x6 or 2x8 scabs, secured with galvanized spiral nails, ensuring robust connections between braces and posts. The construction details emphasize the importance of precise joint configurations, with toenailing and bolting techniques employed to secure wood and steel beams at openings, as detailed in D3 and D4. The assembly sequence prioritizes the installation of trusses and bracing elements to establish a stable framework before cladding and finishing. The design adheres to stringent code compliance standards, with specific references to OBC for ventilation and structural requirements. The fabrication notes highlight the use of metal tracks and 10d nails for continuous purlin splices, ensuring seamless load distribution across the roof plane. The project exemplifies advanced engineering practices, with a focus on load path analysis, material specifications, and construction methodologies tailored to the unique demands of an agricultural storage facility.
